description: From Medieval Latin farsa. Doublet of farce.

entries.meaning: A vernacular paraphrase inserted into Latin liturgy.

description: From Old French farsir. Doublet of farce.

verbs.description: farse (third-person singular simple present farses, present participle farsing, simple past and past participle farsed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To insert vernacular paraphrases into (a Latin liturgy).
examples: There is also evidence of glossing (or farsing) the texts of the Epistles read in the masses of the Christmas Octave.
